audio_caption: The audio begins with a dramatic musical piece, featuring a triumphant fanfare and strings, creating a mood of anticipation. Transitioning into speech, a male voice introduces himself as Chris Kobe with the League of Women Voters of Portland, setting up a video voters guide. He welcomes Keith Wilson, a candidate for the Portland City Council, and asks him to introduce himself and his reasons for running. Keith Wilson responds with a warm greeting and thanks to the League of Women Voters, before expressing concern for the current crisis and best wishes to everyone. He assures that, together, they will get through it.

The clip starts with a man introducing himself as Keith Wilson, stating he was born and raised in Portland. He shares about his family life, mentioning his wife and children, and his educational background at Roosevelt High School and Oregon State. He then describes leaving Portland for many years to travel and work overseas, after which he returned to join his father's business in transportation. He's currently the President of Titan Freight Systems. He continues to describe his wife as an early childhood special education teacher, and says that his kids are doing great. Finally, he mentions he is going to share about some of his focus.

A male speaker begins by describing four key tenets, starting with "our inability to keep our city clean and maintained". He states his expertise as a transportation manager and owner and mentions concerns about homelessness with a plan to address it. He then discusses climate crisis, noting his company, Titan, uses green technology, and he wants to apply that on a larger scale to Portland. His tone is confident and solution-oriented.

The clip starts with one male speaker discussing a "deeply affordable housing crisis," emphasizing the struggle for people who have lived or built the city to afford living there. He mentions having "clear-cut plans" to address it. This is one of the main reasons he's running for Portland City Council.

The clip starts with a male speaker referring to the pandemic as "a major challenge," and further asks, with a tone of concern, about the challenges resulting from it. He references layoffs, devastating small businesses, and repercussions for months and years. A second male speaker begins, speaking more calmly, indicating he will discuss the pandemic.

The audio clip starts with a single male speaker discussing the small business stabilization fund and emphasizing the need for "all hands on deck". He expresses concerns about a potential recession and the importance of investing in the workforce. His tone is serious and focused. A faint, gentle sound of wind appears subtly in the background.

The audio clip features a male speaker enthusiastically describing his experience at Portland Community College, mentioning attending after Roosevelt High School and paying for his own education. He believes it's time to retrain and turn the current crisis—which he describes as both danger and opportunity—into a positive. He emphasizes converting the crisis into opportunity.

The audio features a male speaker discussing the need for government support, local, regional, and national, to retrain the workforce in response to a recession. He advocates for constant evolution, readiness, and utilizing city resources to help businesses survive, ultimately aiding the workforce. Following this, another male speaker responds with a simple acknowledgement, "Okay". The audio concludes with the word "Ellen".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing a discussion about "city government" and noting an "unusual situation." He then inquires about bureaus the listener might be interested in managing if they were a city council member. Another male speaker agrees with what has been stated.

The audio clip begins with someone saying "yes, in fact," followed by an individual who claims to be running for position number four. This person has a master's degree in transportation and finance and ran a complex transportation organization for the past 20 years. They mention being into green transportation, knowing all the facets of running a trucking company, and being a perfect fit. The speaker concludes that the commission and PBOT work perfectly.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the "former city government," arguing that although some individuals like a nurse running the water bureau may be talented, it's inefficient for them to learn technical aspects like pipe sizes when their expertise lies in chemistry and biology. He advocates for a "structured city manager" with expertise in management techniques like key performance indicators and Six Sigma to manage bureau heads and report to the city, suggesting this would be a more effective approach.

The clip begins with a male speaker, seemingly discussing a city's organizational structure and policy-making process with an optimistic tone, saying council people are "legislators" who "focus 100% of our time" on "developing the best policy" and that "the city has nothing to hold it back" if managed well. Another speaker interjects with "very good".

The clip begins with a male speaker requesting one more question, followed by him asking for general comments on law enforcement in the city, specifically addressing police-community relations, use of deadly force, and officer accountability. The same male speaker then requests any thoughts on those topics.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker expressing sadness over a heart-wrenching situation, particularly mentioning the involvement of "mentally ill" individuals in instances of "deadly force," linking this to homelessness. He proceeds to reference a website "Keithforportland.com," highlighting platform items addressing mental illness and homelessness.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing accountability and community-engaged policing. He describes the current program as temporary and expresses the need to make it full-time. He wants the program to have the ability to hold individuals accountable and research transgressions completely. His tone is serious and professional. He mentions the desire for the program to be permanent and integrated into the city structure.

The audio clip features a male speaker advocating for an oversight program, stating the need to "look and hold everybody accountable," and emphasizes supporting both the police and the public. He stresses that "it has to work together to really make Portland safer" and concludes by wanting to "make Portland safer". The overall tone is serious and focused on public safety.

The audio begins with a male speaker expressing appreciation, followed by a reference to taking time and "rolling with the punches." He then identifies the content as the "Visio Voters Guide" and mentions the primary election date, emphasizing the importance of being informed about candidates and ballot measures, and exercising the right to vote. The speaker concludes with a thank you for watching. This speech segment is followed by dramatic music.
